name: Law of the Iterated Logarithm (LIL)
description:
Let $X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n$ be random variables defined on $(\Omega, \mathbb{R})$. If the following three conditions hold:

  1. The random variables are iid.
  2. $\mathbb{E}[X_1]$ exists.
  3. $\text{Var}[X]$ exists (implied by 2.).

Then the error is approximately bounded as follows: $$e_n(\omega)=\left|\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^nX_i(\omega)-\mathbb{E}[X_1]\right|\leq\sqrt{\text{Var}[X]}\sqrt{\frac{2\:\text{ln}\:\text{ln}\:n}{n}}$$ A rigorous version of this approximation is as follows: $$\mathbb{P}\left(\left\{\omega\in\Omega: \limsup_{n\rightarrow\infty}\left|\frac{\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^nX_i(\omega)-\mathbb{E}[X_1]}{\sqrt{\text{Var}[X]}\sqrt{\frac{2\:\text{ln}\:\text{ln}\:n}{n}}}\right| \right\}\right)=1$$
